Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow, glancing at the notice tacked to the break room wall: “Optional Safety Training—Next Week.” The foreman’s already made it clear that those who show up for extra sessions are seen as team players, the kind who get more hours and better shifts. I know how much that matters. But my phone buzzes in my pocket, and I see a message from Maya, my friend from the activist group. She’s live-streaming from a protest downtown, her voice urgent: “We need more people here—if you’re free, come now.” My heart pounds. I want to be there, standing up for what I believe in, but I also know the crew expects me to be reliable, to put the job first. I stare at the notice, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I can’t be in two places at once, and whichever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
